p: Marine protected areas or no‐take marine reserves are the most common form of reef management, focusing predominantly on reducing local anthropogenic pressures (Agardy, di Sciara, & Christie, 2011; Mellin, Aaron MacNeil, Cheal, Emslie, & Julian Caley, 2016). The recent trend in designations of very large, remote MPAs such as the 640,000 km 2 Chagos MPA (Jones & De Santo, 2016) to meet the 10% coverage target of the Convention on Biological Diversity may represent political rather than science‐based interests. These MPAs cost little to designate but may not be effective or representative (Jones & De Santo, 2016). They do not protect the most threatened reefs—those associated with high human population densities—nor address social issues such as maintaining ecosystem services for those reliant on reefs for food or income (Sale et al., 2014). Their designation should not divert attention from management of more damaged coral reefs in highly populated areas.
